docTitle.titlePart: THE MAN IN THE STALLS A PLAY IN ONE ACT

titlePage.docImprint: This play was produced at the Palace Theatre on October 6 ,1911

stage.head: THE MAN IN THE STALLS
stage.stage: The sitting-room of a little flat in Shaftesbury Avenue . At back is a door leading to the dining-room — it is open , and the dinner-table is in full view of the audience . To the extreme right is another door , leading to the hall .

The place is pleasantly and prettily , though quite inexpensively , furnished . To the left , at angles with the distempered wall , is a baby-grand piano ; the fireplace , in which a fire is burning merrily , is on the same side , full centre . To the right of the door leading to the dining-room is a small side-table , on which there is a tray with decanter and glasses ; in front of this , a card-table , open , with two packs of cards on it , and chairs on each side . Another table , a round one , is in the centre of the room — to right and to left of it are comfortable armchairs . Against the right wall is a long sofa ; above it hang a few good , water-colours and engravings ; on the piano and the table there are flowers . A general appearance of refinement and comfort pervades the room ; no luxury , but evidence everywhere of good taste , and the countless feminine touches that make a room homelike and pleasant .

When the curtain rises , HECTOR ALLEN , a youngish man of forty , with an attractive intellectual face , is seen standing by the dining-table in the inner room , draining his liqueur-glass , with WALTER COZENS to the right of him , lighting a cigarette . WALTER is a few years younger than his friend , moderately good-looking , with fine , curly brown hair and a splendid silky moustache . His morning-clothes are conspicuously well-cut — he is evidently something of a dandy ; HECTOR wears a rather shabby dress-suit , his boots are awkward , and his tie ready-made . BETTY , a handsome woman of thirty , wearing a very pretty tea-gown , is talking to the maid at the back of the dining-room .
HECTOR puts down his glass and comes into the sitting-room , followed by WALTER . HECTOR is puffing at a short , stumpy little black cigar .

HECTOR [ Talking as he comes through , continuing the conversation — he walks to the fireplace and stands with his back to it . ] I tell you , if I 'd known what it meant , I 'd never have taken the job ! Sounded so fine , to be reader of plays for the Duke 's Theatre — adviser to the great Mr. Honeyswill ! And then — when the old man said I was to go to all the first nights — why , I just chortled ! “ It 's the first nights that show you the grip of the thing — that teach you most ” — he said . Teach you ! As though there were anything to learn ! Oh my stars ! I tell you , it 's a dog 's life !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Sitting to left of the round table .I 'd change places with you , sonny .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: You would , eh ? That 's what they all say ! Four new plays this week , my lad — one yesterday , one to-day — another to-morrow , and the night after ! All day long I 'm reading plays — and I spend my nights seeing ‘ em ! D'you know I read about two thousand a year ? Divide two thousand by three hundred and sixty five . A dog 's life — that 's what it is !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Better than being a stockbroker 's clerk — you believe me !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Is it ? I wish you could have a turn at it , my bonny boy ! Your hair 'd go grey , like mine ! And look here — what are the plays to-day ? They 're either so chock-full of intellect that they send you to sleep — or they reek of sentiment till you yearn for the smell of a cabbage !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Well , you 've the change , at any rate .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Snorting .Change ? By Jove , give me a Punch and Judy show on the sands — or performing dogs ! Plays — I 'm sick of ‘ em ! And look here — the one I 'm off to to-night . It 's adapted from the French — well , we know what that means . Husband , wife and mistress . Or wife , husband , lover . That 's what a French play means . And you make it English , and pass the Censor , by putting the lady in a mackintosh , and dumping in a curate !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Coming in , and closing the door leading to the dining-room .You ought to be going , Hector .

body.stage: She , stands listening for a moment , then goes through the other door into the hall .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Disregarding her , too intent on his theme .And I tell you , of the two , I prefer the home-made stodge . I 'm sick of the eternal triangle . They always do the same thing . Husband strikes attitudes — sometimes he strikes the lover . The lover never stands up to him — why should n't he ? He would — in real life .BETTY comes back , with his overcoat and muffler — she proceeds affectionately to wrap this round his neck , and helps him on with his coat , he talking all the time .He 'd say , look here , you go to Hell . That 's what he 'd say — well , there you 'd have a situation . But not one of the playwriting chaps dares do it . Why not , I ask you ? There you 'd have truth , something big . But no — they 're afraid — think the public wo n't like it . The husband 's got to down the lover — like a big tom-cat with a mouse — or the author 'd have to sell one of his motor-cars ! That 's just the fact of it !

lg.stage: Looking at the clock on the mantelpiece .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Cheerily .All right , my lass , I 'm off . By-bye , Walter — keep the old woman company for a bit . Good-bye , sweetheart .He kisses her .Do n't wait up . Now for the drama . Oh , the dog 's life !

body.stage: He goes . BETTY waits till the hall door has banged , then she sits on the elbow of WALTER 'S chair , and rests her head on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Softly .Poor Hector !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Uncomfortably .Yes ...

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Does n't it make you feel dreadful when he talks like that ?She kisses him ; then puts her arms round his neck , draws his face to her , and kisses him again , on the cheek .Does n't it ?

body.stage: She nestles contentedly closer to him .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Trying to edge away .Well , it does . Yes .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Dreamily .I — like it .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Betty !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , I like it . I do n't know why . I suppose I 'm frightfully wicked . Or the danger perhaps — I do n't know .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Making a futile effort to get up .Betty —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Tightening her arms around him .Stop there , and do n't move . How smooth your chin is — his scrapes . Why do n't husbands shave better ? Or is it that the forbidden chin is always smoother ? Poor old Hector ! If he could see us ! He has n't a suspicion . I think it 's lovely — really , I do . He leaves us here together , night after night , and imagines you 're teaching me bridge .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Restlessly .So I am . Where are the cards ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Caressing him .Silly , have you forgotten that this is Tuesday — Maggie 's night out ? She 's gone — I told her she need n't wait to clear away . We 've arranged master 's supper . Master ! You 're my master , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I do n't know what I am ...

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Oh yes you do — you 're my boy . Whom I love . There .She kisses him again , full on the lips .That was a nice one , was n't it ? Poor old Hector , sitting in his stall — thinks he 's so wonderful , knows such a lot ! Yes , Maggie 's out — with her young man , I suppose . The world 's full of women , with their young men — and husbands sitting in the stalls .... And I suppose that 's how it always has been , and always will be .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Shifting uneasily .Do n't , Betty — I do n't like it . I mean , he has such confidence in us .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Of course he has . And quite rightly . Are n't you his oldest friend ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: With something of a groan .I 've known him since I was seven .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: The first man he introduced me to — his best man at the wedding — do you remember coming to see us during the honeymoon ? I liked you then .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Really shocked .Betty !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I did . You had a way of squeezing my hand .... And then when we came back here . You know it did n't take me long to discover —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Protesting .I scarcely saw you the first two or three years !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: No — you were afraid . Oh I thought you so silly !He suddenly contrives to release himself — gets up , and moves to the card-table .Why , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: At the table , with his back to her .I hate hearing you talk like this .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Silly boy !She rises , and goes to him ; he has taken a cigarette out of the box on the table , and stands there , with his head bent , tapping the cigarette against his hand .Women only talk “ like this , ” as you call it , to their lovers . They talk “ like that ” to their husbands — and that 's why the husbands never know . That 's why the husbands are always sitting in the stalls , looking on .She puts her arms round him again .Looking and not seeing .

body.stage: She approaches her lips to his — he almost fretfully unclasps her arms .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Betty — I want to say a — serious word ...

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Looking fondly at him .Well , is n't what I 'm saying serious ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I 'm thirty-eight .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes . I 'm only thirty . But I 'm not complaining .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Has it ever occurred to you —

body.stage: He stops .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: What ?

body.stage: WALTER looks at her — tries to speak , but cannot — then he breaks away , goes across the room to the fireplace and stands for a moment looking into the fire . She has remained where she was , her eyes following him wonderingly . Suddenly he stamps his foot violently .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Damn it ! DAMN it !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Moving towards him in alarm .What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: With a swift turn towards her .I 'm going to get married .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Stonily , stopping by the round table .You ...

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Savagely .Going to get married , yes . Married , married !

body.stage: She stands there and does n't stir — does n't speak or try to speak ; merely stands there , and looks at him , giving no sign . Her silence irritates him ; he becomes more and more violent , as though to give himself courage .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: You 're wonderful , you women — you really are . Always contrive to make us seem brutes , or cowards ! I 've wanted to tell you this a dozen times — I 've not had the pluck . Well , to-day I must . Must , do you hear that ?... Oh , for Heaven 's sake , say something .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Still staring helplessly at him .You ...

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Feverishly .Yes , I , I ! Now it 's out , at least — it 's spoken ! I mean to get married , like other men — fooled , too , I dare say , like the others — at least I deserve it ! But I 'm tired , I tell you — tired —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Of me ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Tired of the life I lead — the beastly , empty rooms — the meals at the Club . And I 'm thirty-eight — it 's now or never .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Slowly .And how about — me ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: You ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Passionately .Yes . Me . Me !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: You did n't think this would last for ever ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Nodding her head .I did — yes — I did . Why should n't it ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Working himself into a fury again .Why ? You ask that ? Why ? Oh yes , it 's all right for you — you 've your home and your husband — I 'm there as an — annexe . To be telephoned to , when I 'm wanted , at your beck and call , throw over everything , come when you whistle . And it 's not only that — I tell you it makes me feel — horrid . After all , he 's my — friend .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: He has been that always . You did n't feel — horrid — before .... Who is she ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Shortly , as he turns back to the fire .That does n't matter .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , it does . Who ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Fretfully .Oh , why should we —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I want to know — I 'm entitled to know .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Still with his back to her .Mary Gillingham .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Mary Gillingham !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Firmly , swinging round to her .Yes .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: That child , that chit of a girl !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: She 's twenty-three .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Whom I introduced you to — my own friend ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Grumbling .What has that to do with it ? And besides ...He suddenly changes his tone , noticing how calm she has become — he takes a step towards her , and stands by her side , at the back of the table , his voice becomes gentle and affectionate .But I say , really , you 're taking it awfully well — pluckily . I knew you would — I knew I was an ass to be so — afraid .... And look here , we 'll always be pals — the very best of pals . I 'll ... never forget — never . You may be quite sure ... of that . I want to get married — I do — have a home of my own , and so forth — but you 'll still be — just the one woman I really have loved — the one woman in my life — to whom I owe — everything .

lg.l: Do you tell all that — to Mary

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Pettishly , as he moves away .Do I — do n't be so absurd .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You tell her she is the only girl you have loved .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Moving back to the fire , with his back to her .I tell her — I tell her — what does it matter what I tell her ? And one girl or another — she or someone else —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: But you have n't answered my question — what 's to become of me ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Angrily , facing her .Become of you ! Do n't talk such nonsense . Because it is — really it is . You 'll be as you were . And Hector 's a splendid chap — and after all we 've been frightfully wrong — treating him infernally badly — despicably . Oh yes , we have — and you know it . Lord , there 've been nights when I have — but never mind that — that 's all over ! In future we can look him in the face without feeling guilty — we can —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Quietly .You can .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You can , because of this girl . Oh , I know , of course ! You 'll come here three or four times — then you 'll drop off — you 'll feel I 'm not quite the woman you want your wife to know .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: With genuine feeling , as he impulsively steps towards her .Betty , Betty , what sort of cad do you take me for ? What sort of cad , or bounder ? Have n't I told you I 'd never forget — never ? And you think you 'll pass out of my life — that I want you to ? Why , good Heaven , I 'll be your best friend as long as I live . Friend — yes — what I always should have been — meant to be ! And Hector . Why , Betty , I tell you , merely talking to-night , as I 've done , has made me feel — different — sort of — lifted — a load . Because I 've always had it — somewhere deep down in me — when I 've thought of — him .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Calmly .Liar .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Falling back .Betty !

lg.l: Liar — yes . Why these stupid , silly lies ? “ Always , deep down in me ! ”
Where was it , this beautiful feeling , when you got me to go to your rooms ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Harshly .We need n't —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I liked you — I 've said that — I liked you from the first . But I was straight enough . Liked you , of course — but I had no idea , not the slightest .... Thought it fun to play the fool , flirt just a bit . But it was you , you , you who —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Breaking in sulkily and stamping his foot .Never mind about who it was .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Passionately .Never mind ! You dare !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Doggedly .Yes — I dare . And look here — since you force me to it — that 's all rot — yes , it is — just rot . Just as you like it now , hearing Hector ask me to stop with you , and kissing me the moment his back is turned — so you met me halfway , and more than halfway .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You cur !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: That 's what a woman always says , when a man speaks the truth . Because it is the truth — and you know it . “ The way I squeezed your hand ! ” D'you think I meant to squeeze it — in a way ! Why , as there 's a Heaven above me , you were as sacred to me — as my own sister !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Quietly , as she sits , to right of the table .What I 'm wondering is — you see , you 're the only lover I 've had — what I wonder is , when a man breaks off , tells a woman he 's tired of her , wants to get married — does he always abuse the woman —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Sulkily .I have n't —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Degrade , and throw mud on , the love she has had for him ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: With a bitter shrug .Love —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Passionately , as she springs to her feet .Love , love , yes , you — cruel man ! Love , what else ? I adore you , do n't you know that ? Live for you ! would give up everything in the world — everything , everything ! And Walter , Walter ! If it 's only that — that you want a home — well , let 's go off together . He 'll divorce us — we can get married . Do n't go away , and leave me here , alone with him ! I could n't stand it — Walter , I could n't , I could n't !

body.stage: She goes eagerly to him , flings her arms round his neck , and a dry sob bursts from her .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Very gently .Betty , Betty , you 've been so brave ... Betty , dear , the horrid things I 've said were only to make you angry , to make you feel what a brute I was , how well you 're rid of me . Oh , I 'm not proud of myself ! But look here , we must be sensible — we must , really .... You know , if you were divorced — if I were the co-respondent in a divorce case — I 'd lose my berth , get the sack —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Clinging to him .We could go to Australia — anywhere —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I 've no money .

lg.stage: With a sudden movement , raising her head and leaving him .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: It 's not for her money that I —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: With a start .You love her ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Dropping his head , and speaking under his breath .Yes .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Wringing her hands .You do , you do ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Yes , that 's the truth — I do . Oh , Betty I 'm so frightfully sorry —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: With a groan .Then you do n't love me any more ...

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: It 's not that . But you see —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Moaning .You do n't , you do n't !

body.stage: She stands there , crushed , overwhelmed , dry-eyed , broken moans escaping from her ; suddenly she hears a key turning in the lock of the hall-door outside , and rushes to the card-table .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Hector ! Quick , quick — the cards !

body.stage: WALTER flies to the table , and sits by her side . He seizes one pack and proceeds to shuffle it , she is dealing with the other . All this takes only a second . HECTOR comes in — they both spring up .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Hector ! You 're not ill ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Kissing her .Play postponed , my child — bit of luck ! When I got to the theatre I found that the actor-manager 's car had collided with a cab outside the stage-door — he was thrown through the window — there 's a magnificent exit for you ! and has been cut about a bit . Nothing serious . But the play 's postponed for a week . Bit of luck !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Sitting .Not for him .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Oh he has had luck enough — tons of it ! I 'll get into a jacket — then we 'll have some bridge . See what progress you 've made , Betty !

body.stage: He hurries out , and closes the door .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Producing a little mirror from her bag , looking into it , touching her hair .We were only just in time .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Eagerly , as he bends across the table .You 're splendid — you are — splendid !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes . All very nice and comfortable for you — is n't it ?She puts the mirror back into the bag .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Coaxingly .Betty .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: To-morrow you 'll go to her — or to-night perhaps —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: To-night — ridiculous ! At this hour !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: She 's a deceitful little cat . I saw her last week — she never told me —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I do n't think she knew . I only proposed to-day .

lg.stage: Flinging herself back in her chair , and opening wide eyes .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Very embarrassed .Yes — I mean —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You — proposed — to-day ! And waited till she had accepted you — to tell me —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Eagerly .Do n't be so silly — come , come , he 'll be back in a minute .... And , believe me , I 'm not worth making a fuss about !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Looking contemptuously at him .That 's true .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Yes , it is , worse luck ! I deserve all you 've said to me . And you 'll be ... much better ... without me .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Better ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Yes , better , better — any way you choose to put it ! I 'm a — but never mind that !— Look here — you 'd like me to stop ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: He wants to play bridge .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Do n't you think that I —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Hearing HECTOR coming .Sh .

body.stage: HECTOR comes in — she is idly tossing the cards about . HECTOR has put on a smoking-jacket — he comes in , very jolly , fussing around , rubbing his hands , so glad to be home . He sits , to the right of BETTY .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Now for a game !

body.stage: He seizes a pack , and spreads out the cards .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Leaning back .Not sure that I want to play .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Do n't be disagreeable , Betty ! Why ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Listlessly , as she rises and moves across the room .No fun , being three .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Good practice for you . Come on .

lg.stage: Leaning against the other table , and turning and facing them .
lg.l: Besides , he has something to tell you .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Walter ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Looking inquiringly at WALTER .To tell me ? What is it ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: That he 's engaged .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Shouting , as he leans across the table .Never ! Walter ! Engaged ? You ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Nervously .Yes .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Noisily and affectionately .You old scoundrel ! You rascal and villain ! Engaged — and you do n't come and tell me first ! Well I — am — damned !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Trying to take it gaily .I knew you 'd chaff me about it .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Chaff you ! Silly old coon ! why I 'm glad ! Of course we shall miss you — but marriage — it 's the only thing , my boy — the only thing ! Who is she ? Do I know her ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Mumbling , as he fingers the cards .A friend of Betty 's — I fancy you 've met her —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Mary Gillingham . We 're the first to know — he only proposed to-day .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Gillingham , Gillingham .... Oh yes , I 've seen her , just seen her , but I do n't remember .... I say , not the daughter of the sealing-wax man ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Then there 's lots of tin ! Fine ! Oh you artful old dodger ! Is she pretty ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: So-So .

lg.stage: Still leaning against the table , and looking at them both .
lg.l: She 's excessively pretty . She has yellow hair and blue eyes .
And she has caught old Wallie . The cynical old
Wallie who sniffed at women ! Though perhaps it 's the money —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: No . He 's in love with her .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: That 's good . I 'm glad . And I congratulate you — heartily , my boy .He seizes WALTER 'S hand , and wrings it .We must drink to it !He gets up , goes to the side-table , and pours some whiskey into a tumbler .Charge your glass , Walter !WALTER rises and goes to the side-table .Ladies and gentlemen . I give you the bride and bridegroom !He fills the glass from the syphon and passes it to WALTER , then proceeds to fill his own .Betty , you must join us .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Quietly .No .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: You can n't toast him in water , of course . Has she cleared away yet ? I 'll get you some Hock .

body.stage: He puts his glass down and moves to the door at back .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Do n't be so silly . I wo n't drink at all .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Amazed .Not to old Walter ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Steadily .No .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Almost jeeringly .Because — old Walter — has been my lover .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Stopping , and staring at her .What ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Calmly , looking full at him .My lover ... these last two years .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Staring stupidly at her .He has been —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Impatiently , as she taps the floor with her foot .Yes , yes . How often must I tell you ? My lover — do n't you know what that means ? Why do you stare at me with those fat goggle-eyes of yours ? He has been my lover — and now he has fallen in love with this girl and means to marry her . That 's all .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Turning towards WALTER , who has n't stirred from the side-table .What ? You ?

body.stage: WALTER remains motionless and silent .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: In muffled tones , scarcely able to speak .You ! It 's true what this woman says ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Contemptuously .This woman ! Do n't be so melodramatic ! Have you forgotten my name ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Turning fiercely to her , roaring madly .Silence , Jezebel !She shrinks back , in alarm , towards the fire .Your name ! Wait a bit , I 'll tell you !He takes a step towards her — she crouches in terror against the wall .You shall hear what your name is ! Just now I 'm dealing with him .He swings round to WALTER .You there , you skunk and thief ! You , you lying hound ! I was your best friend . So you 've taken my wife , have you ? And now mean to go off and marry this girl . That 's it ? Oh , it 's so simple ! Here — come here — sit down . Sit down , I tell you . Here , in this chair . Shall I have to drag you to it ? I want to keep my hands off you . Here .WALTER has moved slowly towards him . HECTOR has banged down a chair behind the centre table , WALTER sits in it — HECTOR speaks over his shoulder to BETTY .And you — fetch pen and ink and paper —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: In abject panic .Hector —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Turning fiercely and scowling at her .If you speak to me I 'll brain you too . Just you go in there and fetch the things . D'you hear ? Go .She moves into the other room . HECTOR swings round to WALTER .As for you , you 're a scoundrel . A rogue , a thief , a liar , a traitor . Of the very worst kind , the blackest . Not an ordinary case of a husband and wife — I trusted you — you were my best friend . You spawn , you thing of the gutter , you foul-hearted , damnable slug !

body.stage: BETTY comes back , dragging her feet , carrying paper and envelopes and a stylograph — she puts them on the table .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Not that stylograph — that 's mine — his dirty hands sha n't touch it — I could never use it again . Fetch your pen — yours — you belong to him , do n't you ? Go in and fetch it . D'you hear ?

body.stage: BETTY goes into the inner room again .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: My wife . And you the man I 've done more for than for any one else in the world . The man I cared for , you low dog . Used my house — came here because it was dull at the Club — and took my wife ? I do n't know why I do n't kill you . I 've the right . But I wo n't . You shall pay for it , my fine fellow — you are going to pay — now .

body.stage: BETTY brings a pen and an inkstand ; she places them on the table ; HECTOR seizes them and pushes them in front of WALTER . BETTY slinks to the other side of the room , and stands by the sofa .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: To WALTER .Now you write . You hear ? You write what I dictate . Word for word . What 's the old brute 's name ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Whose ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Whose ! Her father , the sealing-wax man , old Gillingham ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Staring .Gillingham ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Gillingham . Yes . What is it ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: You want me to write to him ?

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Nodding .To him . Who else ? A confession ? I 've had that . His name ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Dropping the pen and half rising .I wo n't —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Springing upon him in a mad fury , and forcing him back into the chair .You wo n't , you dog ! You dare say that — to me ! By Heaven , you will ! You 'll lick the dust off this floor , if I tell you ! You 'll go on your hands and knees , and crawl ! Sit down , you ! Sit down and take up your filthy pen . So .Thoroughly cowed , WALTER has taken up the pen again .And now — his name . Do n't make me ask you again , I tell you , do n't . What is it ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Richard .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Very well , Richard . So write that down . To Richard Gillingham . I have to-day proposed to your daughter , and she has accepted me . Got that ? She has accepted me . But I can n't marry her — can n't marry her — because I have seduced the wife of my friend Hector Allen —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Appealingly , dropping his pen .Hector !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Frantically gripping WALTER by the throat , till he takes up his pen again .The wife of my friend Hector Allen — write it — and plainly , you hound , plainly — so — and because I am taking the woman away with me to-night .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: With a loud cry .Hector !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Over his shoulder , watching WALTER write .Silence , over there , you ! Hold your tongue ! Go into your room and put on your things — we 've done with you here ! Take what you want — I do n't care — you do n't show your face here again . And you —he taps his clenched hand against WALTER 'S armwrite . What are you stopping for ? How far have you got ?He peers over WALTER 'S shoulder .Because — I — am — taking — the — woman — away — with — me — to-night .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Beside herself , wringing her hands .Hector , Hector —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Savagely , as he makes a half-turn towards her .You still there ? Wait a bit . I 'll come to you , when I 've finished with him . If you have n't gone and put on your things , you shall go off without them . Into the street . You 'll find other women there like you .He turns back to WALTER .Here , you , have you written ?He looks over WALTER 'S shoulder .Go on — I 'm getting impatient . Go on , I tell you . I — am — taking — the —

body.stage: WALTER is slowly writing down the words , HECTOR standing over him ; BETTY suddenly bursts into a peal of wild , uproarious laughter , and lets herself fall into a chair to the left of the card-table .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Madly .You !

body.stage: He leaves WALTER , and almost springs at her .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Brimming with merriment .Oh , you old donkey ! How we have pulled your leg !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Staring at her , stopping dead short .You —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Through her laughter , choking .Hector , Hector ! Conventional situations ! The usual stodge ! The lover and husband ! You goose , you wonderful old goose !

body.stage: WALTER , with a mighty effort , has pulled himself together , and roars with laughter too . He jumps up . HECTOR is standing there blinking , paralysed .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Merrily , to BETTY .Oh really , you should n't . You 've given it away too soon !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Too soon ! He 'd have strangled us . Did you ever see such a tiger ?

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Chuckling hugely .He did n't give the lover much chance to stand up to him , did he ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: And was n't he original ! Dog , hound , villain , traitor !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: To say nothing of Jezebel ! Though , between ourselves , I think he meant Messalina !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: And I was to go into the street . But he did let me fill my bag !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I think the playwrights come out on top , I do indeed .He goes to HECTOR , and stands to left of him .Hector , old chap , here 's the letter !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Going to the other side of HECTOR , and dropping a low curtsey .And please , Mr . Husband , was it to be a big bag , or a small bag , and might I have taken the silver teapot ?

body.stage: HECTOR has been standing there stupid , dazed , dumbfounded , too bewildered for his mind to act or thoughts to come to him ; he suddenly bursts into a roar of Titanic , overwhelming laughter . He laughs , and laughs , staggers to the sofa , falls on it , rocks and roars till the tears roll down his cheeks . He sways from side to side , unable to control himself — his laughter is so colossal that the infection catches the others ; theirs becomes genuine too .

lg.stage: With difficulty , trying to control herself .
lg.l: Gillingham ! “ His name , scoundrel , his name ! ”

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Gurgling .With his hand at my throat ! Sit there , villain , and write !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: “ I 'll deal with you presently ! Wait till I 've finished with him ! ”

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: “ Into the street ! ” At least , they do usually say “ into the night ! ”

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Rubbing his eyes and panting for breath .Oh , you pair of blackguards ! Too bad — no , really too bad ! It was ! I fell in , I did ! Oh , Lord , oh , Lord , what a nightmare ! But it was n't right , really it was n't — no really ! My Lord , how I floundered — head and shoulders — swallowed it all ! Comes of reading that muck every day — never stopped to think ! I did n't ! Walter , old chap !He holds out his hand .Betty ! My poor Betty !He draws her towards him .The things I said to you !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Carelessly eluding the caress .At least admit that you 're rather hard on the playwriting people !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Getting up and shaking himself .Oh , they be blowed ! Well , you have had a game with me !He shakes himself again .Brrrrr ! Oh , my Lord ! What I went through !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: It was a lark ! you should have seen yourself ! Your eyes starting out of your head ! You looked like a murderer !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: By Jove , and I felt it ! For two pins I 'd have —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: And Mary Gillingham ! That 's the funniest part ! That you could have thought he was engaged — to her !

body.stage: Involuntarily the smile dies away on WALTER 'S face ; he turns and stares at her ; she goes on calmly .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: When she happens to be the one girl in this world he can n't stand !

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: With a movement that he can n't control .Betty !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Turning smilingly to him .No harm in my telling Hector — he scarcely knows her !She swings round to HECTOR again .Why , Walter simply loathes the poor girl ! That 's what made it so funny !At the mere thought of it she bursts out laughing again , and goes on speaking through her laughter .And I tell you — if you ever hear he 's engaged to her — why , you can believe the rest of the story too !

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Laughing heartily as he pats WALTER on the shoulder .Poor old Walter ! And , d'you know , I was quite pleased at the thought of his getting married ! I was !He turns to him .But it 's better , old chap , for us — we 'd have missed you — terribly !With another pat on WALTER 'S shoulder , he goes to the fire , and drops in the letter .Must n't leave that lying about !He turns .Well , by Jove , if any one had told me .... And drinking to him , and all !

lg.l: If you 'll fetch me that glass of Hock now , I will drink to him ,

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Beaming .So we will ! Good . I 'll get it .

body.stage: He bustles into the dining-room .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Moving swiftly to WALTER .Well , now 's your time . One thing or the other .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Savagely .You fiend !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I 'll go and see her to-morrow — see her constantly —

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: Why are you doing this ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You 've ruined my life and his . At least , you sha n't be happy .

lg.l: And you imagine I 'll come back to you — that we 'll go on , you and

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Scornfully .No — do n't be afraid ! You 've shown yourself to me to-day . That 's all done with — finished . His friend now — with the load off you — but never her husband . Never !

body.stage: HECTOR comes bustling back , with the bottle of Hock , and a wine-glass that he gives to BETTY — she holds it , and he fills it from the bottle .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Here you are , my girl — and now , where 's my whiskey ?He trots round to the side table , finds his glass , and WALTER 'S — hands one to WALTER .Here , Wallie — yours must be the one that 's begun — I did n't have time to touch mine ! Here .WALTER takes it .And forgive me , old man , for thinking , even one minute —He wrings him by the hand .Here 's to you , old friend . And Betty , to you ! Oh , Lord , I just want this drink !

lg.stage: In cold , clear tones , as she holds up her glass .

body.stage: She drains her glass ; WALTER has his moment 's hesitation ; he drinks , and with tremendous effort succeeds in composing his face .

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Gaily .To Walter , the Bachelor !He drinks his glass to the dregs and puts it down .And now — for a game .

sp.speaker: WALTER
sp.p: I think I —

sp.speaker: HECTOR
sp.p: Coaxingly .Sit down , laddie — just one rubber . It 's quite early . Do . There 's a good chap .They all sit : HECTOR at back , BETTY to the left of him , WALTER to the right — he spreads out the cards — they draw for partners .As we are — you and Betty — I 've got the dummy .He shuffles the cards — BETTY cuts — he begins to deal .That 's how I like it — one on each side of me . Also I like having dummy . Now , Betty , play up . Oh , Lord , how good it is , how good ! A nightmare , I tell you — terrible ! And really you must forgive me for being such an ass . But the way you played up , both of you ! My little Betty — a Duse , that 's what she is — a real Duse !He gathers up his cards .And the gods are kind to me — I 've got a hand , I tell you ! I call NO TRUMPS !

body.stage: He beams at them — they are placidly sorting their cards . He puts his hand down and proceeds to look at his dummy , as the curtain falls .
CURTAIN
