stage.head: A MARRIAGE HAS BEEN ARRANGED ....
stage.stage: SCENE The conservatory of No . 300 Grosvenor Square . Hour , close on midnight . A ball is in progress , and dreamy waltz music is heard in the distance .
LADY ALINE DE VAUX enters , leaning on the arm of MR. HARRISON CROCKSTEAD .

LADY ALINE is a tall , exquisitely-gowned girl , of the conventional and much-admired type of beauty . Put her in any drawing-room in the world , and she would at once be recognised as a highborn Englishwoman . She has in her , in embryo , all those excellent qualities that go to make a great lady : the icy stare , the haughty movement of the shoulder , the disdainful arch of the lip ; she has also , but only an experienced observer would notice it , something of wistfulness , something that speaks of a sore and wounded heart — though it is sufficiently evident that this organ is kept under admirable control . A girl who has been placed in a position of life where artificiality rules , who has been taught to be artificial and has thoroughly learned her lesson ; yet one who would unhesitatingly know the proper thing to do did a camel bolt with her in the desert , or an eastern potentate invite her to become his two hundred and fifty-seventh wife . In a word , a lady of complete self-possession and magnificent control . MR. CROCKSTEAD is a big , burly man of forty or so , and of the kind to whom the ordinary West End butler would consider himself perfectly justified in declaring that her ladyship was not at home . And yet his evening clothes sit well on him ; and there is a certain air of command about the man that would have made the butler uncomfortable . That functionary would have excused himself by declaring that MR. CROCKSTEAD did n't look a gentleman . And perhaps he does n't . His walk is rather a slouch ; he has a way of keeping his hands in his pockets , and of jerking out his sentences ; a way , above all , of seeming perfectly indifferent to the comfort of the people he happens to be addressing . The impression he gives is one of power , not of refinement ; and the massive face , with its heavy lines , and eyes that are usually veiled , seems to give no clue whatever to the character of the man within .
The couple break apart when they enter the room ; LADY ALINE is the least bit nervous , though she shows no trace of it ; MR. CROCKSTEAD absolutely imperturbable and undisturbed .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Looking around .Ah — this is the place — very quiet , retired , romantic — et cetera . Music in the distance — all very appropriate and sentimental .

body.stage: She leaves him , and sits , quietly fanning herself ; he stands , looking at her . ] You seem perfectly calm , Lady Aline ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Sitting .Conservatories are not unusual appendages to a ball-room , Mr. Crockstead ; nor is this conservatory unlike other conservatories . CROCKSTEADTurning to her .I wonder why women are always so evasive ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: With your permission we will not discuss the sex . You and I are too old to be cynical , and too young to be appreciative . And besides , it is a rule of mine , whenever I sit out a dance , that my partner shall avoid the subjects of women — and golf .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: You limit the area of conversation . But then , in this particular instance , I take it , we have not come here to talk ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Coldly .I beg your pardon !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Sitting beside her .Lady Aline , they are dancing a cotillon in there , so we have half an hour before us . We shall not be disturbed , for the Duchess , your aunt , has considerately stationed her aged companion in the corridor , with instructions to ward off intruders .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Very surprised .Mr. Crockstead !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Looking hard at her .Did n't you know ?ALINE turns aside , embarrassed .That 's right — of course you did . Do n't you know why I have brought you here ? That 's right ; of course you do . The Duchess , your aunt , and the Marchioness , your mother — observe how fondly my tongue trips out the titles — smiled sweetly on us as we left the ball-room . There will be a notice in the Morning Post to-morrow : “ A Marriage Has Been Arranged Between — ”

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Bewildered and offended .Mr. Crockstead ! This — this is —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Always in the same quiet tone .Because I have not yet proposed , you mean ? Of course I intend to , Lady Aline . Only as I know that you will accept me —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: In icy tones , as she rises .Let us go back to the ball-room .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Quite undisturbed .Oh , please ! That wo n't help us , you know . Do sit down . I assure you I have never proposed before , so that naturally I am a trifle nervous . Of course I know that we are only supers really , without much of a speaking part ; but the spirit moves me to gag , in the absence of the stage-manager , who is , let us say , the Duchess —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I have heard of the New Humour , Mr. Crockstead , though I confess I have never understood it . This may be an exquisite example —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: By no means . I am merely trying to do the right thing , though perhaps not the conventional one . Before making you the formal offer of my hand and fortune , which amounts to a little over three millions —

lg.l: How people exaggerate ! Between six and seven ,

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Only three at present , but we must be patient . Before throwing myself at your feet , metaphorically , I am anxious that you should know something of the man whom you are about to marry .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: That is really most considerate !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I have the advantage of you , you see , inasmuch as you have many dear friends , who have told me all about you .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: With growing exasperation , but keeping very cool .Indeed ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I am aware , for instance , that this is your ninth season —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Snapping her fan .You are remarkably well-informed .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I have been told that again to-night , three times , by charming young women who vowed that they loved you . Now , as I have no dearest friends , it is unlikely that you will have heard anything equally definite concerning myself . I propose to enlighten you .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Satirically .The story of your life — how thrilling !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I trust you may find it so .He sits , and pauses for a moment , then begins , very quietly .Lady Aline , I am a self-made man , as the foolish phrase has it — a man whose early years were spent in savage and desolate places , where the devil had much to say ; a man in whom whatever there once had been of natural kindness was very soon kicked out . I was poor , and lonely , for thirty-two years : I have been rich , and lonely , for ten . My millions have been made honestly enough ; but poverty and wretchedness had left their mark on me , and you will find very few men with a good word to say for Harrison Crockstead . I have no polish , or culture , or tastes . Art wearies me , literature sends me to sleep —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: When you come to the chapter of your personal deficiencies , Mr. Crockstead , please remember that they are sufficiently evident for me to have already observed them .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Without a trace of annoyance .That is true . I will pass , then , to more intimate matters . In a little township in Australia — a horrible place where there was gold — I met a woman whom I loved . She was what is technically known as a bad woman . She ran away with another man . I tracked them to Texas , and in a mining camp there I shot the man . I wanted to take the woman back , but she refused . That has been my solitary love affair ; and I shall never love any woman again as I loved her . I think that is all that I have to tell you . And now — will you marry me , Lady Aline ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Very steadily , facing him .Not if you were the last man in this world , Mr. Crockstead .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: With a pleasant smile .At least that is emphatic .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: See , I will give you confidence for confidence . This is , as you suggest , my ninth season . Living in an absurd milieu where marriage with a wealthy man is regarded as the one aim in life , I have , during the past few weeks , done all that lay in my power to wring a proposal from you .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I appreciate your sincerity .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Perhaps the knowledge that other women were doing the same lent a little zest to the pursuit , which otherwise would have been very dreary ; for I confess that your personality did not — especially appeal to me .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Cheerfully .Thank you very much .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Not at all . Indeed , this room being the Palace of Truth , I will admit that it was only by thinking hard of your three millions that I have been able to conceal the weariness I have felt in your society . And now will you marry me , Mr. Crockstead ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Serenely .I fancy that 's what we 're here for , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Stamping her foot .I have , of course , been debarred from the disreputable amours on which you linger so fondly ; but I loved a soldier cousin of mine , and would have run away with him had my mother not packed me off in time . He went to India , and I stayed here ; but he is the only man I have loved or ever shall love . Further , let me tell you I am twenty-eight ; I have always been poor — I hate poverty , and it has soured me no less than you . Dress is the thing in life I care for most , vulgarity my chief abomination . And to be frank , I consider you the most vulgar person I have ever met . Will you still marry me , Mr. Crockstead ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: With undiminished cheerfulness .Why not ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: This is an outrage . Am I a horse , do you think , or a ballet-dancer ? Do you imagine I will sell myself to you for your three millions ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Logic , my dear Lady Aline , is evidently not one of your more special possessions . For , had it not been for my — somewhat eccentric preliminaries — you would have accepted me , would you not ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Embarrassed .I — I —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: If I had said to you , timidly : “ Lady Aline , I love you : I am a simple , unsophisticated person ; will you marry me ? ” You would have answered , “ Yes , Harrison , I will . ”

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: It is a mercy to have escaped marrying a man with such a Christian name as Harrison .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: It has been in the family for generations , you know ; but it is a strange thing that I am always called Harrison , and that no one ever adopts the diminutive .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: That does not surprise me : we have no pet name for the East wind .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: The possession of millions , you see , Lady Aline , puts you into eternal quarantine . It is a kind of yellow fever , with the difference that people are perpetually anxious to catch your complaint . But we digress . To return to the question of our marriage —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I presume that it is — arranged ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Haughtily .Mr. Crockstead , let me remind you that frankness has its limits : exceeding these , it is apt to degenerate into impertinence . Be good enough to conduct me to the ball-room .

body.stage: She moves to the door .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: You have five sisters , I believe , Lady Aline ?ALINE stops short .All younger than yourself , all marriageable , and all unmarried ?

body.stage: ALINE hangs her head and is silent .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Your father —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Fiercely .Not a word of my father !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Your father is a gentleman . The breed is rare , and very fine when you get it . But he is exceedingly poor . People marry for money nowadays ; and your mother will be very unhappy if this marriage of ours falls through .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Moving a step towards him .Is it to oblige my mother , then , that you desire to marry me ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Well , no . But you see I must marry some one , in mere self-defence ; and honestly , I think you will do at least as well as any one else .ALINE bursts out laughing .That strikes you as funny ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: If you had the least grain of chivalrous feeling , you would realise that the man who could speak to a woman as you have spoken to me —

body.stage: She pauses .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I leave you to finish the sentence .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Thank you . I will finish it my own way . I will say that when a woman deliberately tries to wring an offer of marriage from a man whom she does not love , she deserves to be spoken to as I have spoken to you , Lady Aline .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Scornfully .Love ! What has love to do with marriage ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: That remark rings hollow . You have been good enough to tell me of your cousin , whom you did love —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: And with whom you would have eloped , had your mother not prevented you .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I most certainly should .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: So you see that at one period of your life you thought differently .— You were very fond of him ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I have told you .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Meditatively .If I had been he , mother or no mother , money or no money , I would have carried you off . I fancy it must be pleasant to be loved by you , Lady Aline .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Dropping a mock curtsey , as she sits on the sofa .You do me too much honour .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Still thoughtful , moving about the room .Next to being king , it is good to be maker of kings . Where is this cousin now ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: In America . But might I suggest that we have exhausted the subject ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Do you remember your “ Arabian Nights , ” Lady Aline ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Vaguely .

lg.l: You have at least not forgotten that sublime Caliph , Haroun

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Oh , no — but why ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: We millionaires are the Caliphs to-day ; and we command more faithful than ever bowed to them . And , like that old scoundrel Haroun , we may at times permit ourselves a respectable impulse . What is your cousin 's address ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Again I ask — why ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I will put him in a position to marry you .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: In extreme surprise .She rises .What !

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Oh , do n't be alarmed , I 'll manage it pleasantly . I 'll give him tips , shares , speculate for him , make him a director of one or two of my companies . He shall have an income of four thousand a year . You can live on that .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: You are not serious ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Oh yes ; and though men may not like me , they always trust my word . You may .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: And why will you do this thing ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Call it caprice — call it a mere vulgar desire to let my magnificence dazzle you — call it the less vulgar desire to know that my money has made you happy with the man you love .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: That is generous .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I remember an old poem I learnt at school — which told how Frederick the Great coveted a mill that adjoined a favourite estate of his ; but the miller refused to sell . Frederick could have turned him out , of course — there was not very much public opinion in those days — but he respected the miller 's firmness , and left him in solid possession . And mark that , at that very same time , he annexed — in other words stole — the province of Silesia .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Ah —

lg.l: “ Ce sont là jeux de Princes :

body.stage: The music stops .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: You speak French ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I am fond of it . It is the true and native language of insincerity .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: And yet you seem sincere .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I am permitting myself that luxury to-night . I am uncorking , let us say , the one bottle of ‘ 47 port left in my cellar .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: You are not quite fair to yourself , perhaps .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Do not let this action of mine cause you too suddenly to alter your opinion . The verdict you pronounced before was , on the whole , just .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: What verdict ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I was the most unpleasant person you ever had met .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: That was an exaggeration .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: The most repulsive —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Quickly .I did not say that .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: And who prided himself on his repulsiveness . Very true , in the main , and yet consider ! My wealth dates back ten years ; till then I had known hunger , and every kind of sorrow and despair . I had stretched out longing arms to the world , but not a heart opened to me . And suddenly , when the taste of men 's cruelty was bitter in my mouth , capricious fortune snatched me from abject poverty and gave me delirious wealth . I was ploughing a barren field , and flung up a nugget . From that moment gold dogged my footsteps . I enriched the few friends I had — they turned howlingly from me because I did not give them more . I showered money on whoever sought it of me — they cursed me because it was mine to give . In my poverty there had been the bond of common sorrow between me and my fellows : in my wealth I stand alone , a modern Ishmael , with every man 's hand against me .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Gently .Why do you tell me this ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Because I am no longer asking you to marry me . Because you are the first person in all these years who has been truthful and frank with me . And because , perhaps , in the happiness that will , I trust , be yours , I want you to think kindly of me .She puts out her hand , he takes it .And now , shall we return to the ball-room ? The music has stopped ; they must be going to supper .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: What shall I say to the Marchioness , my mother , and the Duchess , my aunt ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: You will acquaint those noble ladies with the fact of your having refused me .

body.stage: They have both risen , and move up the room together .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I shall be a nine days ’ wonder . And how do you propose to carry out your little scheme ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I will take Saturday 's boat — you will give me a line to your cousin . I had better state the case plainly to him , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: That demands consideration .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: And I will tell you what you shall do for me in return . Find me a wife ! ALINE . I ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: You . I beg it on my knees . I give you carte blanche . I undertake to propose , with my eyes shut , to the woman you shall select .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: And will you treat her to the — little preliminaries — with which you have favoured me ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: No . I said those things to you because I liked you .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: And you do n't intend to like the other one ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I will marry her , I can trust you to find me a loyal and intelligent woman .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: In Society ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: For preference . She will be better versed in spending money than a governess , or country parson 's daughter .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: But why this voracity for marriage ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Lady Aline , I am hunted , pestered , worried , persecuted . I have settled two breach of promise actions already , though Heaven knows I did no more than remark it was a fine day , or enquire after the lady 's health . If you do not help me , some energetic woman will capture me — I feel it — and bully me for the rest of my days . I raise a despairing cry to you — Find me a wife !

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Do you desire the lady to have any — special qualifications ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: No — the home-grown article will do . One thing , though — I should like her to be — merciful .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I have a vague desire to do something with my money : my wife might help me . I should like her to have pity .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Pity ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: In the midst of her wealth I should wish her to be sorry for those who are poor .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Yes . And , as regards the rest —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: The rest I leave to you , with absolute confidence . You will help me ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I will try . My choice is to be final ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Absolutely .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I have an intimate friend — I wonder whether she would do ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Tell me about her .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: She and I made our debut the same season . Like myself she has hitherto been her mother 's despair .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Because she has not yet —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Married — yes . Oh , if men knew how hard the lot is of the portionless girl , who has to sit , and smile , and wait , with a very desolate heart — they would think less unkindly of her , perhaps —She smiles .But I am digressing , too .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Tell me more of your friend .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: She is outwardly hard , and a trifle bitter , but I fancy sunshine would thaw her . There has not been much happiness in her life .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Would she marry a man she did not love ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: If she did you would not respect her ?

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I do n't say that . She will be your choice ; and therefore deserving of confidence . Is she handsome ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Well — no .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: With a quick glance at her .That 's a pity . But we can n't have everything .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: No . There is one episode in her life that I feel she would like you to know —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: If you are not betraying a confidence —

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Looking down .No . She loved a man , years ago , very dearly . They were too poor to marry , but they vowed to wait . Within six months she learned that he was engaged .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: To a fat and wealthy widow —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: The old story .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Who was touring through India , and had been made love to by every unmarried officer in the regiment . She chose him .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: India ?He moves towards her .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: I have an idea that I shall like your friend .He takes her hand in his .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: I shall be careful to tell her all that you said to me — at the beginning —

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: It is quite possible that my remarks may not apply after all .

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: But I believe myself from what I know of you both that — if she marries you — it will not be — altogether — for your money .

sp.speaker: CROCKSTEAD
sp.p: Listen — they 're playing “ God Save the King . ” Will you be my wife , Aline ?

sp.speaker: ALINE
sp.p: Yes — Harry .

body.stage: He takes her in his arms and kisses her .
CURTAIN

docTitle.titlePart: THE MAN ON THE KERB A DUOLOGUE

body.stage: TIME — The present
SCENE — Their home in the West End
Produced at the Aldwych Theatre on March 24 , 1908

stage.head: THE MAN ON THE KERB
stage.stage: SCENE : An underground room , bare of any furniture except two or three broken chairs , a tattered mattress on the stone floor and an old trunk . On a packing-chest are a few pots and pans and a kettle . A few sacks are spread over the floor , close to the empty grate ; the walls are discoloured , with plentiful signs of damp oozing through . Close to the door , at back , is a window , looking on to the area ; two of the panes are broken and stuffed with paper .

On the mattress a child is sleeping , covered with a tattered old mantle ; MARY is bending over her , crooning a song . The woman is still quite young , and must have been very pretty ; but her cheeks are hollow and there are great circles round her eyes ; her face is very pale and bloodless . Her dress is painfully worn and shabby , but displays pathetic attempts at neatness . The only light in the room comes from the street lamp on the pavement above .

JOE comes down the area steps , and enters . His clothes are of the familiar colourless , shapeless kind one sees at street corners ; he would be a pleasant-looking young fellow enough were it not that his face is abnormally lined , and pinched , and weather-beaten . He shambles in , with the intense weariness of a man who has for hours been forcing benumbed limbs to move ; he shakes himself , on the threshold , dog-fashion , to get rid of the rain . MARY first makes sure that the child is asleep , then rises eagerly and goes to him . Her face falls as she notes his air of dejection .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Wistfully .Nothing , Joe ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Nothing . Not a farthing . Nothing .

body.stage: MARY turns away and checks a moan .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Nothing at all . Same as yesterday — worse than yesterday — I did bring home a few coppers — And you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: A lady gave Minnie some food —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Heartily .Bless her for that !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Took her into the pastrycook 's , Joe —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: And the kiddie had a tuck-out ? Thank God ! And you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Minnie managed to hide a great big bun for me .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: The lady did n't give you anything ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Only a lecture , Joe , for bringing the child out on so bitter a day .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: With a sour laugh , as he sits on a chair .Ho , ho ! Always so ready with their lectures , are n't they ? “ Should n't beg , my man ! Never give to beggars in the street ! ” — Look at me , I said to one of them . Feel my arm . Tap my chest . I tell you I 'm starving , and they 're starving at home .— “ Never give to beggars in the street . ”

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Laying a hand on his arm .Oh , Joe , you 're wet !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: It 's been raining hard the last three hours — pouring . My stars , it 's cold . Could n't we raise a bit of fire , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With what , Joe ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: After a look round , suddenly getting up , seizing a ricketty chair by the wall , breaking off the legs .With this ! Wonderful fine furniture they give you on the Hire System — so solid and substantial — as advertised .He breaks the flimsy thing up , as he speaks .And to think we paid for this muck , in the days we were human beings — paid about three times its value ! And to think of the poor devils , poor devils like us , who sweated their life-blood out to make it — and of the blood-sucking devils who sold it and got fat on it — and now back it goes to the devil it came from , and we can at least get warm for a minute .He crams the wood into the grate .Got any paper , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Taking an old newspaper from the trunk .Here , Joe .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: That will help to build up a fire .He glances at it , then lays it carefully underneath the wood . MARY gets lamp from table .The Daily Something or other — that tells the world what a happy people we are — how proud of belonging to an Empire on which the sun never sets . And I 'd sell Gibraltar to-night for a sausage with mashed potatoes ; and let Russia take India if some one would give me a clerkship at a pound a week .— There , in you go ! A match , Mary ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Standing above JOE , handing him one .Ok Joe , be careful — we 've only two left !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I 'll be careful . Wait , though — I 'll see whether there 's a bit of tobacco still in my pipe .He fishes the pipe out of his pocket .A policeman who warned me away from the kerb gave me some tobacco . “ Must n't beg , ” he said . “ Got a pipe ? Well , here 's some tobacco . ” I believe he 'd have given me money . But it was the first kind word I had heard all day , and it choked me .— There 's just a bit left at the bottom .He bustles .Now , first the fire .He puts the match to the paper — it kindles .And then my pipe .The fire burns up ; he throws himself in front of it .Boo-o-oh , I 'm sizzling .... I got so wet that I felt the water running into my lungs — my feet did n't seem to belong to me — and as for my head and nose !Yawns .Well , smoke 's good — by the powers , I 'm getting warm — come closer to it , Mary . It 's a little after midnight now — and I left home , this fine , luxurious British home , just as soon as it was light . And I 've tramped the streets all day . Net result , a policeman gave me a pipeful of tobacco , I lunched off a bit of bread that I saw floating down the gutter — and I dined off the kitchen smell of the Café Royal . That 's my day .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Stroking his hand .Poor boy , poor boy !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I stood for an hour in Leicester Square when the theatres emptied , thinking I might earn a copper , calling a cab , or something . There they were , all streaming out , happy and clean and warm — broughams and motor-cars — supper at the Savoy and the Carlton — and a hundred or two of us others in the gutter , hungry — looking at them . They went off to their supper — it was pouring , and I got soaked — and there I stood , dodging the policemen , dodging the horses ’ heads and the motors — and it was always — get away , you loafer , get away — get away — get away —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: We 've done nothing to deserve it , Joe —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: With sudden fury .Deserve it ! What have I ever done wrong ! Was n't my fault the firm went bankrupt and I could n't get another job . I 've a first-rate character — I 'm respectable — what 's the use ? I want to work — they wo n't let me !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That illness of mine ate up all our savings . O Joe , I wish I had died !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: And left me alone ? That 's not kind of you , Mary . How about Mrs. Willis ? Is she worrying about the rent ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Well , she 'd like to have it , of course — they 're so dreadfully poor themselves — but she says she wo n't turn us out . And I 'm going to-morrow to her daughter 's upstairs — she makes matchboxes , you know — and I do n't see why I should n't try — I could earn nearly a shilling a day .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: A shilling a day ! Princely !His pipe goes out . He takes a last puff at it , squints into it to make sure all the tobacco is gone , then lays it down with a sigh .I reckon I 'll try making ‘ em too . I went to the Vestry again , this morning , to see whether they 'd take me as sweeper — but they 've thirty names down , ahead of me . I 've tried chopping wood , but I can n't — I begin to cough the third stroke — there 's something wrong with me inside , somewhere . I 've tried every Institution on God 's earth — and there are others before me , and there is no vacancy , and I must n't beg , and I must n't worry the gentlemen . A shilling a day — can one earn as much as that ! Why , Mary , that will be fourteen shillings a week — an income ! We 'll do it !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It 's not quite a shilling , Joe — you have to find your own paste and odds and ends . And of course it takes a few weeks to learn , before you begin to make any money .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Crestfallen .Does it though ? And what are we going to do , those few weeks ? I thought there was a catch in it , somewhere .He gets up and stretches himself .Well , here 's a free-born Englishman , able to conduct correspondence in three languages , bookkeeping by double entry , twelve years ’ experience — and all he 's allowed to do is to starve .He stretches himself again .But in spite of all temptations To belong to other nations —

body.stage: With sudden passion . ] God ! I wish I were a Zulu !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Edging to him .Joe —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Turning .Well ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Joe , Joe , we 've tried very hard , have n't we ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Tried ! Is there a job in this world we 'd refuse ? Is there anything we 'd turn up our nose at ? Is there any chance we 've neglected ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Stealing nervously to him and laying a hand on his arm .Joe —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Raising his head and looking at her .Yes — what is it ?She stands timidly with downcast eyes .Well ? Out with it , Mary !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Suddenly .It 's this , Joe .

body.stage: She goes feverishly to the mattress , and from underneath it she pulls out a big , fat purse which she hands him .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Staring .A purse !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Nodding .Yes .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Found it .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Looking at her .Found ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Awkwardly .In a way I did — yes .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It came on to rain , Joe — and I went into a Tube Station — and was standing by a bookstall , showing Minnie the illustrated papers — and an old lady bought one — and she took out her purse — this purse — and paid for it — and laid the purse on the board while she fumbled to pick up her skirts — and then some one spoke to her — a friend , I suppose — and — there were lots of people standing about — I do n't know how it was — I was out in the street , with Minnie —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You had the purse ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Yes —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: No one followed you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No one . I could n't run , as I had to carry Minnie .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: What made you do it ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I do n't know — something in me did it — She put the purse down just by the side of my hand — my fingers clutched it before I knew — and I was out in the street .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: How much is there in it ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I have n't looked , Joe .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Wondering .You have n't looked ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: No ; I did n't dare .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Sorrowfully .I did n't think we 'd come to this , Mary .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Desperately .We 've got to do something . Before we can earn any money at making matchboxes we 'll have to spend some weeks learning . And you 've not had a decent meal for a month — nor have I . If there 's money inside this purse you can get some clothes — and for me too — I need them ! It 's not as though the old lady would miss it — she 's rich enough — her cloak was real sable — and no one can find us out — they can n't tell one piece of money from the other . It 's heavy , Joe — I think there 's a lot inside .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Weighing it mechanically .Yes — it 's heavy —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Eagerly .Open it , Joe .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Turning to her again .Why did n't you ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I just thought I 'd wait — I 'd an idea something might have happened ; that some one might have stopped you in the street , some one with a heart — and that he 'd have come in with you to-night — and seen us — seen Minnie — and said — “ Well , here 's money — I 'll put you on your legs again ” — And then we 'd have given the purse back , Joe .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: As he still mechanically balances it in his hand .Yes .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Ca n't go on like this , can we ? You 'll cough all night again , as you did yesterday — and the stuff they gave you at the Dispensary 's no good . If you had clothes , you might get some sort of a job perhaps — you know you had to give up trying because you were so shabby .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: They laugh at me .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With a glance at herself .And I 'm really ashamed to walk through the streets —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I know — though I 'm getting used to it . Besides , there 's the kiddie . Let 's have a look at her .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Be careful you do n't wake her , Joe !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: There 's a fire .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: She 'll be hungry .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: You said that she had some food ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: That was at three o'clock . And little things are n't like us — they want their regular meals . Night after night she has been hungry , and I 've had nothing to give her . That 's why I took the purse .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Still holding it mechanically and staring at it .Yes . And , after all , why not ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: We can get the poor little thing some warm clothes , some good food —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Under his breath .A thief 's daughter .

body.stage: Covers his face with his hands .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Joe !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Not nice , is it ? Ca n't be helped , of course . And who cares ? For three months this game has gone on — we getting shabbier , wretcheder , hungrier — no one bothers — all they say is “ keep off the pavement . ” Let 's see what 's in the purse .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Eagerly .Yes , yes !

lg.stage: Lifting his head as he is on the point of opening the purse .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Impatiently .Never mind that —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Turning to the purse again .First time in my life I 've been afraid when I heard the policeman .

body.stage: He has his finger on the catch of the purse when he pauses for a moment — then acting on a sudden impulse , makes a dart for the door , opens it , and is out , and up the area steps .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With a despairing cry .Joe !

body.stage: She flings herself on the mattress , and sobs silently , so as not to awaken , the child . JOE returns , hanging his head , dragging one foot before the other .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Still sobbing , but trying to control herself .Why did you do that ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Humbly .I do n't know —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You gave it to the policeman ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: What did you tell him ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: That you had found it .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: In a Tube Station . Picked it up because we were starving . That we had n't opened it . And that we lived here , in this cellar .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With a little shake .I expect he 'll keep it himself !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Miserably .Perhaps .

body.stage: There is silence for a moment ; she has ceased to cry ; suddenly she raises herself violently on her elbow .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You fool ! You fool !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Pleading .Mary !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With your stupid ideas of honesty ! What have they done for you , or me ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Dropping his head again .It 's the kiddie , you know — her being a thief 's daughter —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Is that worse than being the daughter of a pair of miserable beggars ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Under his breath .I suppose it is , somehow —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You 'd rather she went hungry ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Despairingly .I do n't know how it was — hearing his tramp up there —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You were afraid ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I do n't want you taken to prison .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: With a wail .I 'll be taken to the graveyard soon , in a pauper 's coffin !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Starts suddenly .Suppose we did that ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Staring .The workhouse ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Why not , after all ? That 's what it will come to , sooner or later .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: They 'd separate us .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: At least you and the kiddie 'd have food .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: They 'd separate us . And I love you , Joe . My poor , poor Joe ! I love you .

body.stage: She nestles up to him and takes his hand .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Holding her hand in his , and bending over her .You forgive me for returning the purse ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Dropping her head on his shoulder .Forgive you ! You were right . It was the cold and the hunger maddened me . You were right !

lg.stage: Springing to his feet , with sudden passion . MARY staggers back .
lg.l: I was n't right — I was a coward , a criminal — a vile and wicked fool .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Startled .Joe !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I had money there — money in my hand — money that you need so badly , you , the woman I love with all my ragged soul — money that would have put food into the body of my little girl — money that was mine , that belonged to me — and I 've given it back , because of my rotten honesty ! What right have I to be honest ? They 've made a dog of me — what business had I to remember I was a man ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Following him and laying a hand on his arm .Hush , Joe — you 'll wake Minnie .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Turning and staring haggardly at her .I could have got clothes — a job , perhaps — we might have left this cellar . We could have gone out to-morrow and bought things — gone into shops — we might have had food , coal —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Do n't , Joe — what 's the use ? And who knows — it may prove a blessing to us . You told the policeman where we lived ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: A blessing ! I 'll get up to-morrow , after having coughed out my lungs all night — and I 'll go into the streets and walk there from left to right and from right to left , standing at this corner and at that , peering into men 's faces , watching people go to their shops and their offices , people who are warm and comfortable — and so it will go on , till the end comes .

lg.stage: Standing very close to him , almost in a whisper .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: With a startled glance at her .The end ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: There 's no room for us in this world —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: If I 'd taken that money —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It 's too late for that now . And I 'm glad you did n't — yes , I am — I 'm glad . We 'll go before God clean-handed . And we 'll say to Him we did n't steal , or do anything He did n't want us too . And we 'll tell Him we 've died because people would n't allow us to live .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: With a shudder .No . Not that — we 'll wait , Mary . Do n't speak of that .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Wistfully .You 've thought of it too ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Thought of it ! Do n't , Mary , do n't ! It 's bad enough , in the night , when I lie there and think of to-morrow ! Something will happen — it must .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: What ? We have n't a friend in the world .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: I may meet some one I used to know .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You 've met them before — they always refuse —

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Passionately .I 've done nothing wrong — I have n't drunk or gambled — I can n't help being only a clerk , and unable to do heavy work ! I can n't help my lungs being weak ! I 've a wife and a child , like other people — and all we ask is to be allowed to live !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Pleading .Let 's give it up , Joe . Go away together , you 'd sleep without coughing . Sleep , that 's all . And God will be kinder than men .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Groaning .Do n't , Mary — do n't !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Joe , I can n't stand it any longer — I can n't . Not only myself — but Minnie — Joe , it 's too much for me ! I can n't stand Minnie crying , and asking me for her breakfast , as she will in the morning . Joe , dear Joe , let there be no morning !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Completely overcome .Oh , Mary , Mary !

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: It 's not your fault , dear — you 've done what you could . Not your fault they wo n't let you work — you 've tried hard enough . And no woman ever had a better husband than you 've been to me . I love you , dear Joe . And let 's do it — let 's make an end . And take Minnie with us .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Springing up .Mary , I 'll steal something to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: And they 'd send you to prison . Besides , then God would be angry . Now we can go to Him and need not be ashamed . Let us , dear Joe — oh , do let us ! I 'm so tired !

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Sorrowfully .You wo n't ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Doggedly .No . We 'll go to the workhouse .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You 've seen them in there , have n't you ?

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: You 've seen them standing at the window , staring at the world ? And they 'd take you away from me .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: That 's better than —

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Firmly .I wo n't do it , Joe . I 've been a good wife to you — I 've been a good mother : and I love you , though I 'm ragged and have pawned all my clothes ; and I 'll strangle myself rather than go to the workhouse and be shut away from you .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: With a loud cry .No ! I 'll make them give me something ; and if I have to kill , it sha n't be my wife and child ! To-morrow I 'll come home with food and money — to-morrow —

body.stage: There is a sudden wail from the child ; JOE stops and stares at her ; MARY goes quickly to the mattress and soothes the little girl .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Hush , dear , hush — no it 's not morning yet , not time for breakfast . Go to sleep again , dear . Yes , daddy 's come back , and things are going to be all right now — No , dear , you can n't be hungry , really — remember those beautiful cakes . Go to sleep , Minnie , dear . You 're cold ?She takes off her ragged shawl and wraps it round the child .There , dear , you wo n't be cold now . Go to sleep , Minnie —

body.stage: The child 's wail dies away , as MARY soothes her back to sleep .

sp.speaker: JOE
sp.p: Staggering forward with a sudden cry .God , O God , give us bread ! THE CURTAIN SLOWLY FALLS

stage.head: THE OPEN DOOR
stage.stage: SCENE : The drawing-room of LORD TORMINSTER 'S cottage by the sea . It is 2 a. m. of a fine July night ; the French windows are open on to the lawn . The room is dark ; in an armchair , SIR GEOFFREY TRANSOM , a man of forty , with a frank , pleasant face , is seated , deep in thought . Suddenly the door opens , and LADY TORMINSTER appears and switches on the light . She starts at seeing SIR GEOFFREY .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Rising .Hullo ! Do n't be afraid — it 's only I !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: What a start you gave me Why have n't you gone to bed ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I 'm tired of going to bed . One always has to get up again , and it becomes monotonous . Why have n't you gone to sleep ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I do n't know — it 's too hot , or something . I 've come for a book .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Let me choose one for you .

body.stage: He goes to the table .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why were you sitting in the dark ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Because the light annoyed me . What sort of book will you have ? A red one or a green one ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Is there a virtue in the colour of the binding ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Why not ? They 're all the same inside . There are three hundred ways , they say , of cooking a potato — there are as many of dressing up a lie , and calling it a novel . But it 's always the same old lie . Here take this .He hands her a book .Popular Astronomy . That will send you to sleep .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: The stars frighten me . But I 'll try it . Good-night .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And you really had better go to bed .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I move as an amendment that you sit down and talk .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: At this time of night !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Why not ? It 's day in the Antipodes .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And in this attire !

body.stage: She glances at her peignoir .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Pooh ! You are more dressed than you were at dinner . That 's awfully rude , is n't it ? But then , you see , you 're not my hostess now — you 're a spirit , walking in the night . One can n't be polite to spirits . Sit down , oh shade , and let us converse .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Hesitating .I do n't know —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: The household have all retired ; and we will make this concession to Mrs. Grundy — we will leave the door open . There !He flings it open .The Open Door ! Centuries ago , when I was alive , I remember paragraphs with that heading .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Laughing .So you 're not alive now ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Sir Geoffrey Transom ceased to be when he said good-night to Lady Torminster . Sir Geoffrey is upstairs asleep . So is her ladyship . We are their souls . Let us talk .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You are in your whimsical mood .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: And you in your wrapper — peignoir — tea gown — it do n't matter what you call it . You look — jolly . Ridiculous word — I do n't mean that at all . You look — you . More you than I 've seen you for years . Sh — do n't interrupt . Shades never do that . By the way , do you know that the old lumber-room , my owner — my corporeal sheath — means to go away in the morning , before you are up ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Sir Geoffrey ! What nonsense ! You 've promised to stay a month !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I assure you I have been charged to invent fitting and appropriate lies to account for the ridiculous creature 's abrupt departure . The man Transom is a poor liar .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You are making me giddy . Would you mind putting on your body ? I 've not been introduced to your soul .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Springing up with a flourish .How very remiss of me ! Permit me . Gertrude this is Geoffrey . You have often heard me speak of him .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Rising .I think I 'll go to bed .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Now that is preposterous . Jack , my dear old friend — the best and only friend I have in the world — is slumbering peacefully upstairs , and Jack 's wife is reluctant to talk to Jack 's old pal because the sun happens to be hidden on the other side of the globe . Lady Torminster , sit down . If you 're good you shall have a cigarette .

lg.l: Well , just one . And when I 've finished it ,

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Agreed .

body.stage: He hands her the box ; she takes a cigarette ; he strikes a match and holds it for her ; he then takes a cigarette himself , and lights it .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: And , while smoking it , remember Penelope 's web . For I 've heaps of things to tell you .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: They 'll keep till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: That 's a fearful delusion . Nothing keeps . There is one law in the universe : NOW .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I want to know what you mean by this nonsense about your going .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Puffing out smoke .Yes — I 'm off in the morning . It has occurred to me that I have n't been to China . Now that is a serious omission . How can I face my forefathers , and confess to them that I have n't seen the land where the Yellow Labour comes from ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: China has waited a long time — a month more or less will make no difference . They are a patient race .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: There is gipsy blood in my veins — I must wander — I 'm restless .... Not like Jack — he 's untroubled — he can sleep . Jack 's a fine sleeper , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Calm , serene , untroubled , with the conscience of a babe — one , two , three , he sleeps . He and I have had some rare times together . I 've been roped to him on the Andes — he shot a tiger that was about to scrunch me — I rubbed his nose when it was frost-bitten . He saved my life — I saved his nose . I always maintain that the balance of gratitude is on his side — for where would he have been without his nose ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You are absurd .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Would you have married him without a nose ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I might have .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Now you know you would n't . You 'd have been afraid of what people would say . And what would he have done when he became short-sighted , and had to wear glasses ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: My cigarette has gone out .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Jumping up and handing her the box .Take another . Never re-light a cigarette — it 's like dragging up the past . Here .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I said only one .

lg.l: This is not the hour for inflexibility . The Medes and
Persians have all gone to bed .

body.stage: She takes the cigarette ; he lights it for her .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Tell me why you mean to leave us . And remember — I sha n't let this one go out .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: My explanation will be handed to you with your cup of tea in the morning .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And you will be gone ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I shall be gone . There is a train at 7. 45 — which will be packed with husbands . I shall breakfast in town .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Well , one must breakfast somewhere . It 's a convention .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Sir Geoffrey , I want you to tell me what this means .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Give your decision , said the judge to the arbitrator , but never your reasons . I go , because I go . Besides , has one reasons ? Why do people die , or get married , or buy umbrellas ? Because of typhoid , love , or the rain ? Not at all . Is n't that so ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I wish you 'd be serious .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I 'm fearfully serious . When Jack shot that tiger he had to go so near the brute that he held his life in his hands . Do you know what was my chief impression as I lay there , with the ugly cat 's paw upon my chest , beginning to rip me ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Shuddering .Horrible ! What ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I resented his having eaten something that smelt like onions .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Smiling .A tiger !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Onions may have been his undoing . That 's the beggar 's skin on the floor . But you should have seen me rub Jack 's nose !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Warningly .Sir Geoffrey , there 's very little cigarette left —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: There are lots more in the box — and dawn is a long way off . Hang it , Lady Torminster , do n't be in a hurry ! Do you hear the sea out there ? It 's breathing as regularly as old Jack . And do n't you think this is fine ? Here we are , we two , meeting just as we shall meet on the other side of the Never-Never Land . It 's a chance for a man to speak to a woman , and tell her things .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: What things !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: That 's just it — what things ? What have I to say , after all ? I am going to-morrow because I am a fantastic , capricious ass . Also because I 'm lonely .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: How will China help you ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: They colour it green on the map — and there is such a lot of it !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You should get married .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a sudden burst of passion .You say that — you !

body.stage: He starts back , ashamed , and hangs his head . LADY TORMINSTER throws a quick glance at him , then looks ahead of her , puffing quietly at her cigarette .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Quietly .So that is why you are going ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a great sigh of relief .Now , that really is fine of you ! Every other woman in the world would have seized that chance for a melodramatic exit . “ Good-night , Sir Geoffrey ; I must go to my husband . ” “ Good-night , Lady Torminster . ” A clasp of the hand — a hot tear — mine — on your wrist . But you sit there . Splendid !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I ask you again — is that truly why you are going ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Well , yes , that 's the fact . I apologise humbly — it 's so conventional . Is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I suppose it 's difficult for human beings to invent new situations .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: You 've known it , of course , all the time ; you 've known it ever since Jack brought me to you , the day after you were engaged . And that 's nine years ago . It 's the usual kind of fatality .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: These things happen .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Yes . Well , I thought I was cured . I 've been here five days , and I find I am not . So I go . That 's best , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: It 's so infernally stupid . You 're a beautiful woman , of course ; but there are heaps of beautiful women . You 've qualities — well , so have other women , too . I 'm only forty-one — and , as you say , why do n't I marry ? Simply because of you . Because you 've an uncomfortable knack of intruding between me and the other lady .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: That is a great misfortune .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: It 's most annoying . So I shall try China . I shall come back in two years — I shall be forty-three then — I shall come back , sound as a bell ; and I shall marry some healthy , pink-cheeked young woman , take a house next to yours , and in the fulness of time your eldest son shall fall in love with my daughter .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I should n't have told you , of course ; but I 'm glad that I have . It clears the air . Now what excuse shall I make ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: A wire from town ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Jack knows all about my affairs ; in fact , that 's why I take the early train , to avoid his questions .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You find it impossible to stay out your time here ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Quite . There are moments when I am unpleasantly volcanic .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Then I tell you the best thing to do . Do n't take your trunks ; just go up with a bag . Leave a note that you 'll come back on Tuesday . Then write from town and say you 're prevented .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: That 's a good idea — yes , that 's much better .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And , if you find that you really cannot come back —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Exactly ; you 'll forward my goods and chattels . And old Jack will ascribe it all to my wayward mood ; he 'll think I have found it too dull down here . I 'm immensely obliged .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: With a smile .Remark that I 've not offered to be a sister to you .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: You 've been superb . Oh , the good talk we 've had ! Do you know , I could almost wish old Jack to have heard what I said . I 'm so fond of him , that grand old fellow , that I 've been on the point of telling him , myself , more than once . For you know he will have me take you about , and it 's painful . Besides , I 've felt it almost disloyal to — keep this thing from him . You understand , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: He and I almost are one , you see . It 's not British to show any feeling , but really I — love him . And the devil comes along , and , of all women in the world , singles out Jack 's wife , and fills my heart with her . That 's the devil 's sense of humour .

lg.l: Perhaps he has read Bernard Shaw . But you must never let

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I suppose not . He 's so direct , so single-minded , that the shock would be terrible . But I 'm not to blame . How could I help it ? Oh , all that cackle about being master of one 's fate !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Two years in China —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: We 'll hope so . Of course , it did n't matter about my telling you , because you knew already .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: NoddingYes , I knew . Although —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Oh , you 've done what you could ! I 've felt , in a hundred subtle ways , how you almost implored me — not to . Well , there it is . I 'll write that note at once .

body.stage: He sits at the table and begins to write .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I 'm sorry you are so lonely .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: That 's my fault , too — the fault of the ridiculous class to which we belong . I do n't do anything .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: What would you have me do ? Go into the House ? Thank you , I 've been there . You spend your time on the Terrace or in the smoke-room till a muffin-bell rings ; then you gravely walk into the lobby , where an energetic gentleman counts you as Polyphemus counted his sheep . Philanthropy ! Well , I 've tried that , but it 's not in my line . I 'm quite a respectable landlord , but a fellow can n't live all by himself in a great Elizabethan barrack . Town — the Season ? Christian mothers invite you to inspect their daughters ’ shoulders , with a view to purchase . I 'm tired of golf and polo ; I 'm tired of bridge . So I 'll try the good sea and the open plains ; sleep in a tent and watch the stars twinkle — the stars that make you afraid .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Yes , I 'm afraid of the stars .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You remember the Persian poet ? “ I too have said to the stars and the wind , I will . But the wind and the stars have mocked me — they have laughed in my face .... ”

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: A little uncomfortable .Persian poets , like all poets , have a funny way of pretending that the stars take an interest in us . To me , it 's their chief charm that they 're so unconcerned . They are lonely , too .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Suddenly , violently .Do n't say that again — do n't — I can n't bear it !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Aghast .Gertrude !! !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: In a whisper .Yes .

body.stage: He stares haggardly at her ; she does not move , but looks out , through the open window , into the night .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a deep breath .Well , I suppose we had better turn in —

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: When do you go to China ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I shall take the first boat .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And you will come back —?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: In a year — or two — or three —

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: We shall hear from you ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With an effort of lightness .Certainly . And I will send you chests of tea — best family Souchong — and jars of ginger . Also little boxes that fit into each other . I am afraid that is all I know at present of Chinese manufactures .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Musing .You will be away so long ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: You told me to do something . I shall learn Chinese . I believe there are five hundred letters in the alphabet .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: As many as that !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: It is possible that I exaggerate . Well , Lady Torminster , I think I 'll say good-night .

body.stage: He offers his hand , which she ignores . She smiles , and motions him back to his seat .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: The sun is still shining in the antipodes , my dear Geoffrey , and you are still Jack 's old friend , talking to Jack 's wife . Sit down , and do n't be foolish . You 'll be away for years ; it 's possible we may never meet again . It 's possible , too , that next time we do meet you may be married .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With iron control .Who knows ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Exactly — who knows ? So there 's no reason why we should n't look each other squarely in the face for once , and speak out what 's in us .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Sorrowfully .Oh , Lady Torminster , what is there to say ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Bending forward a little and smiling .How you resent my having told you !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a guilty start .Resent ! I !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You do , and you know it . In your heart you are saying , “ All was going so well — she has spoiled it ! If she does love me she should n't have said it — Jack 's wife ! ”

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Sturdily .Well — Jack 's wife . Yes !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Geoffrey , Jack bores me .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Aghast .Lady Torminster !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Clapping her hands in glee .There ! I 've said it ! Oh , it 's such a relief ! I never have before , and I do n't suppose I ever shall again — for whom can I say it to but you ? Listen — I tell you — quite entre nous — he bores me shockingly !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: In positive distress .Lady Torminster ! I beg of you !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Cheerfully .The best fellow in all the world , and he bores me . A heart of gold , a model husband , a perfect father — and a bore , bore , bore ! There ! I assure you I feel better .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: I suppose there are moments when every woman says that of every man .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Fanning herself .My dear Geoffrey , please send for your soul ; it has wandered off somewhere , and I do n't like talking to copybooks .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Doggedly .You are talking to Jack 's friend .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Jack 's friend — and mine — do n't forget that ! And could I say these things about Jack to any one else , and can n't you conceive what a joy it is to say them ? Besides , are n't we just now on the rim of the world — are n't we a little more than ourselves — are n't we almost on the other side of things ? If we ever meet again , we shall look curiously at each other , and wonder , was it all true ? As it is , I am scarcely sure that you are real . Everything is so still , so strange . Jack ! He is up there , of course , the dear boy , his big red face pressed on the pillow . Oh , Geoffrey , when Jack brought you to me , and I was engaged — if you only had n't been so loyal !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Grimly .Do you know what you are saying ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I am saying the things a woman says once in a lifetime , and feels all her life . Oh , it was all so simple ! You loved me — you ... were blind because of Jack ... And I married Jack ... I must n't complain ... I am one of the hundreds of women who marry — Jacks .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: A better , finer man never lived .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I dare say — in fact , I am sure . But you should see us when we are alone , sitting there night after night , with never a word to say to each other ! You tell me you 're tired of polo , and golf , and bridge . Well , how about me ? And need you be scowling so fiercely , and begrudge me my one little wail , you who are going away ?

lg.l: Yes , I am going away , and I shall marry a
Chinese . I shall marry the first Chinese woman I meet .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: This is very sudden . Why ?

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Because , at least , not knowing the language , she wo n't be able to say unkind things about me to my friends .

lg.stage: Her chin on her hand , looking squarely at him .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: He never bores me .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: That 's because he shot your tiger , and you rubbed his nose . Besides , you talk about horses , and so on . And yet I heard him , for a solid hour , telling you about a rubber he lost at bridge through his partner making diamonds trumps when he should have made spades .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: He 's not clever , of course — and you are . But still ! Is cleverness everything ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Have n't I told you he 's the very best fellow in all the world ? And do you think I 'm posing , pretending that I 'm misunderstood , and the rest ? You know me better . I am indulging , for once , in the luxury of absolute candour .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: You loved him —

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Of course I loved him — and I love him now .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Triumphantly .You see !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: If we women had had a hand in the making of the language , how many words there would be to express our feelings towards the men we are fond of ! Of course I love Jack . I 'm cruel to him sometimes ; and there comes a look into his eyes — he has dog 's eyes , you know — a faithful Newfoundland —

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Very earnestly .I do n't think women quite realise what friendship means to a man .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I am certain that men do n't realise what marriage means to a woman ! Dear funeral , am I not a good wife — shall I not remain a good wife , till the end of the chapter ? Because there is n't only Jack — there are Jack 's children .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And is n't it wonderful , when you think of it — here are we two , Jack 's friend and his wife , alone on a desert island — and we have confessed our love for each other , and we are able to discuss it as calmly as though it were rheumatism !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a groan .If only I had n't induced you to stay !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Smiling .My dear friend , you did n't !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Amazed .I did n't ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why no — of course not . I knew you were going to-morrow .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Oh , never mind how ! I knew . And I suspected you would be sitting up here to-night . So I came down , hoping to find you . I wanted this talk with you . And I extracted your confession — as though it had been a tooth .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: And why ?

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Why ? Because it will be something to think of , in the dull days ahead . Because I knew that you loved me , and wanted to be told . Because your life lies before you , and mine is ended . Because I love you , and insisted that you should know . You leave me now , and I have no illusions . Paolo and Francesca are merely a poet 's dream . You will marry — of course you will marry — but this moment , at least , has been mine .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Stretching out yearning hands .This moment , and every moment , in past and future !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Ah , the future ! Strange little syllables that hide so much ! I can see you , introducing your wife to me , a little shyly — I can see myself , shaking hands with her — and with you .... My boy is seven already — time travels fast .... But it 's good to know that you really have loved me , all these years ....

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: By day and by night — you , and only you !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: And I have loved you — ah , yes , I have loved you !... And , having said this to each other , we will not meet again — till you bring me your wife .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Ah — then !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: I have loved you , and I love you , for the fine , upright , loyal creature that you are . I love you for loving Jack ; and it is Jack 's great quality in my eyes that he has been able to inspire such love . And , my dear friend , let us not be ashamed , we two , but only very proud , and very happy . We shall go our ways , and do our duty ; but we shall never forget this talk we have had to-night .

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: Gently .I am beginning to understand ....

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: You will be less lonely in future ... and I no longer afraid of the stars .... Brave heart — oh , brave little heart that I for a moment have held in my hands !

sp.speaker: SIR GEOFFREY
sp.p: With a passionate movement towards her .Gertrude !

sp.speaker: LADY TORMINSTER
sp.p: Lifting a finger .No — stay where you are .... Those are the first rays of dawn — I must go .... Good-bye . We have no need to shake hands , you and I .... Ah , Geoffrey — good-bye !

body.stage: She goes swiftly , and closes the door . He bends his head , and remains standing , motionless , by the table .
CURTAIN
